...HEARTS. AND TO THEMSELVES IN THESE DAYS THAT TRY THEIR
THE RICH AND BITTER DEPTH OF THEIR EXPERIENCE,
THE LONGING OF BLACK MEN MUST HAVE RESPECT --
...FINER SPIRITS BOON AND GUERDON FOR WHAT THEY LOSE ON E
...THE CHANCE TO SOAR IN THE DIM BLUE AIR ABOVE SMOKE IS
OF VIEW AND MAKE THEIR LOVING, LIVING, AND DOING PRECIOUS

dialogues.speaker: FADE IN
dialogues.text: Before titles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is a clear but cold Autumn night at some time in the n Landsdown Woods are an assortment of various elements of streams, rushing rivers, heavy brushland, small trees, an great tall pines. NATHAN LEE MORGAN, a Black man in his l early forties, treks deep into the woods with his eleven LEE, and his hound dog, SOUNDER. NATHAN LEE is a well bui a man with a deliberate and quiet manner - DAVID LEE, lik and strong with big, bright active eyes. SOUNDER, their h mixture of red-bone hound and bulldog, with great square

dialogues.speaker: TITLES BEGIN
dialogues.text: NATHAN LEE carries an old rifle, and a burlap sack thrown -- DAVID LEE walks with a lantern as SOUNDER tracks ahead moving until they come upon a quiet river stream --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They walk along the edges of the river, with deliberation they have walked this route many times. They reach a cut- back into the woods, and pick up a pathway --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They pick up speed in close approach to a weeded area and about in disappointment. SOUNDER scratches the earth -- N the darkness with a nagging expression on his face --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There ain't no possums in this woods tonight,  Daddy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looks that way, son. Guess the cold done drove  most of 'em down to the big water country --  but if there's one left out here -- we gotta  find him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's cold, Daddy!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here, put my jacket over you. NATHAN takes his jacket off and drapes it over the boy's begins to scratch and whine with intensity. He moves to s

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You all right, boy? Suddenly SOUNDER's voice lets out and he breaks away in a NATHAN and DAVID react quickly and take up the chase behi

dialogues.speaker: TITLES BEGIN AGAIN
dialogues.text: As SOUNDER makes his way through the woods -- NATHAN and him, following the great unique sound of the dog's voice. bounces -- soulful, louder and clearer than any purebred spaced with precision, bouncing from slope to slope like filling up the night with music as though the branches of being pulled across silver strings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SOUNDER arrives and makes a leap to climb the tree as NAT on to the scene. NATHAN looks up and points to the spot w He puts his rifle down near him, and DAVID assists him in tree as SOUNDER makes his leaps upward to the rhythm of t his voice. The possum gives way to the force and falls to charges for the animal -- NATHAN quickly picks up his rif animal. He fires into blank darkness and misses. The poss fall and scampers into thick brushland, with SOUNDER in c

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SOUNDER cannot overcome the briar thickness of the brushl possum with his smaller size manages to elude the dog.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SOUNDER comes out of the brush area, whining in frustrati DAVID approach him. NATHAN immediately realizes that the away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (slams his rifle to the ground)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dammit! And I remember the time when a bull  couldn't a stopped him from gettin' that  possum! DAVID LEE kneels down and caresses SOUNDER's frame. NATHA DAVID is disturbed over his harshness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come here, son-- DAVID LEE goes to his father, who kneels to him, and puts hands on the boy's shoulders.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's all right. He did his job -- I just got  foolish for a minute. He gives the boy a quick embrace and rises to his feet --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If anybody's to blame, it's me -- I oughta  nailed him when I took that shot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was too dark, Daddy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. We better git back to house now. NATHAN puts his hand on SOUNDER's neck, gives him an affe gather their equipment and head for home. They move out o to a pathway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This area of the road is about ten hundred feet from the cabin. The yard is wide, and stretches out to the very ed which comes to a horseshoe deadend about two hundred feet their cabin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In all the years me and Sounder been tracking  down possums and coons in these woods -- he  ain't tore one of 'em up yet... He always  brought 'em back whole and healthy... And  that's the difference between a hound dog  that's dirty and mean, to one that's great  like ol' Sounder here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They move through the yard, up the steps, on to the porch to the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NATHAN, DAVID, and SOUNDER step into the cabin. It is an the home of the Morgan family so it is kept neat and clea one side of the area is a kitchen table, a wood stove, an cabinet. To the other side are two old rockers, an old dr two pieces of other old living room furniture -- there ar this area: the backdoor in the kitchen section which lead and two in the sitting room which leads to the childrens' REBECCA's rooms. REBECCA MORGAN, an attractive brown-skin woman in her thi rocker by the stove alone, picking kernels out of walnut hairpin. She looks up to NATHAN as he stands just inside down at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We cornered one, but he got away. He does not wait for a response from her -- he, DAVID and across the floor, and on out the back door. REBECCA's eye backs out the door. Her eyes just hang there after they h sight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The shed is medium in size and old like the house. There running along side the right wall. There are hanging nail walls and alongside the table. The various pieces of arch are all neatly put in organized places. NATHAN, DAVID and shed. NATHAN hangs the burlap sack on one of the wall nai rifle down on the table -- DAVID does likewise with the l

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bet you're a tired little fellow, David Lee. NATHAN takes the lantern apart and begins to clean it -- up a small can of oil and puts it on top of the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You oughta be tired, too, Sounder. That possum  shore whipped the hell outta you tonight! He laughs behind his own remark as he finishes the busine and picks up his rifle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He beat you, too, Daddy, and you had a big ol'  shootin' rifle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (serious)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boy, you don't make funny with your daddy like  that. His father has caught him off guard -- he was only joking understand the attitude -- he doesn't know what to say -- away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David Lee...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (stops and turns)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You had a rough time out there tonight -- so  you stay home from that school tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wanna go -- the trip don't bother me none.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You learnin' anything at that school?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir -- I learn to write a little bit, and  I can read a lot-- NATHAN LEE looks on him for a moment, and then softly nod

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Readin' must be somethin' powerful, huh, son?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir... NATHAN LEE slams the rifle closed, moves towards the exit out into the backyard -- DAVID LEE and SOUNDER follow him

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The backyard spreads out in the form of a jagged horsesho levels of grass -- at the far end is a pathway, running a feet away to where the tall grass grows. The shed sits to and more to the right edge is a water well. To the right a woodpile. Up against the house, to the right of the ste are two wash tubs with homemade scrubbing boards. NATHAN directly to the water well, reaches it and lowers the buc well, brings the bucket of water up, scoops up with a dip tries to look out over the plains and hills from the back

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When the fall comes in these parts, the Night  moon runs away like a rabbit -- you could stay  out here lookin' all night, and not see a thing  out yonder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We goin' huntin' again tomorrow ?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yep. I guess you must wonder why though, what  with the luck we havin', but like I always  say--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "You lose some of the time, what you always go  afta, but you lose all the time what you don't go afta!"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now who says I didn't lay my mark on you, boy! They both laugh as REBECCA steps out into the backyard fr moves swiftly towards them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David Lee, it's time for you to get to bed!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goodnight.  He starts moving away towards the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Night, son!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And don't wake up Josie Mae and Earl! They watch DAVID LEE enter the house -- then NATHAN LEE l they begin to move for the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your bedtime too, hound dog. SOUNDER hops up on him -- he strokes the dog's back and t

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Off you go, boy! SOUNDER scampers away around the side of the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I bet you could use a hot cup of coffee, Nathan  Lee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I shore could, Miss Rebecca. They start back into the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SOUNDER crawls just under the front porch and lies down o his night's sleep. INT. THE CHILDREN's ROOM - NIGHT DAVID LEE has taken some of the walnuts and is sitting up and JOSIE MAE, their sister, are fast asleep across from sprightly little boy about eight years of age who has the that gives one the impression that he is forever smiling. book and starts to read.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NATHAN and REBECCA enter the house through the back door the table in the kitchen area as REBECCA moves directly t children's room -- just before she gets to the door, she bowl of walnuts on the floor by the rocker has been distu the bowl up from the floor and looks to NATHAN --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The boy done went into my walnuts! I skin my  fingers to the bone to pick two pounds that's  worth almost nothing at the commissary and he  done took almost half of what I pick!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The boy is hungry, Rebecca. His words cut through her frustration -- she puts down th dresser next to the door that leads to the children's roo there for a moment -- she and NATHAN, looking directly on a moment she moves across the floor and nestles into the -- he holds her close to him for a moment and then they b

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dammit! He moves halfway across the floor and stops as REBECCA go prepare his coffee --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We been through these off-seasons before -- we  made it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What we make it to? The next season to work  ourselves to death, share croppin' for ol' man  Howard, so he can get richer and we can't even  eat when the croppin' time is done? His coffee is ready -- she puts it on the table -- he mov and takes a sip with the frustration still nagging him. S from behind and puts her hand on his strong neck for a mo moves for the children's room and enters -- he drinks his INT. REBECCA and NATHAN'S BEDROOM - NIGHT  REBECCA enters, unrobes and crawls into bed -- she lies t thought, rolls over to position herself and then she hear SLAM. She raises her head for a moment and then she decid puts her clothes back on hurriedly and moves out of the r

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: REBECCA moves with directness through the room, on out do

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: REBECCA stands in middle of the backyard, looking about i

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (softly).

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nathan? There is not a sound -- then she moves hastily around the to the front yard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks down under the edge of the porch to see SOUNDER turns and tries to see through the darkness down the road up on the porch and stands in the doorway looking out int begins to hum -- the kind of hum to relax the nerves -- t away from the mind -- thoughts that were plaguing her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is about six a.m. the following morning and hot food i stove.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DAVID LEE awakes first and catches the aroma of the food room. He jumps out of bed and arouses JOSIE MAE and EARL.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on y'all, git up, somethin's cookin' in  the kitchen! Come on, Earl! They all jump into their clothes and rush for the kitchen

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They head straight for the stove where DAVID takes the li pots and then the other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's in there, David!?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sausage and hambones!  EARL tries to put his hand in one of the pots but DAVID s

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't do that!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where did it come from? JOSIE MAE is a tall, pretty girl for her nine years -- wi brooding air about her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on! DAVID sees SOUNDER through the front-door screen, scratch hurriedly lets the dog in, and they all dash out the back

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: REBECCA is hanging out wash on the clothes line as the ch her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mama, there's hot meat on the stove!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where did it come from, Mama?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where all meat come from -- now git yourself  washed up and be snappy about it -- you got six  miles ahead of you to that school. She heads for the kitchen while the children proceed to w

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: REBECCA enters the kitchen and immediately starts prepari NATHAN is awakened and is standing in the doorway to the room. She notices him and stops her work for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good mornin', Nathan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mornin'...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You ready to eat?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll wait till after the children. She goes back to preparing the food as she moves into the together some scraps of food for SOUNDER.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How's the weather out there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Little chilly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hope it don't freeze out our baseball game  today!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The children meet NATHAN as he is coming out of the house to enter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mornin', Daddy!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mornin' back atcha! They rush on past him into the house as he smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't forget to save me some! He stops in the center of the yard and looks about.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sounder! SOUNDER comes running toward him from the field in back o bends to a pan on the ground and puts the scraps of food arrives and begins to eat. NATHAN rises and looks on, ple

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That oughta put you in good shape for tonight!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The children are at the table eating as REBECCA is about laundry work in the backyard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't take all day at that table, David Lee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mama, when kin me and Earl go to school with  David Lee?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe soon-- She moves out of the door --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Out in the backyard, NATHAN is chopping wood with SOUNDER REBECCA returns to hanging out the wash. She starts that and occasionally glances over to him at the woodpile. He moment and calls out to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The one thing we got plenty of is wood! She stops her work and just looks on him with concern whe EARL dash out into the yard, breaking her trend of though

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ready to go, Mama!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tuck that shirt in, David Lee.  He moves toward her, cramming the shirt down into his pan

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got two shirts on?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes mam...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When you get outta that school, you come right  on back home, y'all gon' have to take this  laundry work I done for Miss Boatwright today. She gives him a quick hug and kiss. He rushes over to his

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Bye, Daddy...  They shake hands...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Bye, son...  He takes off with JOSIE MAE, EARL and SOUNDER. REBECCA starts back toward the clothesline, and as if to stops and turns to NATHAN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where was it you went last night, Nathan? He rises from his chopping position and faces her directl

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I went where I had to go, Rebecca. My children  was hungry. As if to say the conversation is over, he immediately goe wood. She gives him a long but soft look and then finally

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DAVID LEE rides in the back of the wagon of a white farme a lift part of the way. DAVID LEE runs a distance of the road -- sits and rests o road for a few minutes -- walks at a slow pace for a whil The boy climbs up into the wagon of a black farmer -- The He makes the final dash up the road.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He speeds around the side of the building, and enters thr

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He rushes down the short hallway until he comes to a door

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is a Southern White school where they segregate off one or two black children they allow to attend the school DAVID LEE enters the room in an exhausted state as he sto door. All eyes are upon him, including a black boy and girl who in the back corner of the room. The teacher picks up his and looks at it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, Mr Clay...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are one hour late...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yessir...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, take your seat. DAVID LEE, with all eyes still upon him, moves carefully far corner -- sits next to the black boy and girl. MR CLA from the desk, and looks out on the class --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now where were we before we were interrupted-- Oh yeah, Huckleberry Finn, chapter thirty-four!  This chapter is called: WE CHEER UP JIM! Here  we go: "Tom says: What's the vittles for?  Going to feed the dogs? The colored boy kind of  smiled around gradually over his face, and  says: Yes, Mars Sid, a dog. Cur'us dog, too.  Does you want to go en look at 'im?" CLOSE ANGLE - DAVID and other two children. The teacher's heard as he continues with the reading -- as the CHILDREN expressions of confusion, pain, and mostly boredom. A hea moment --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is a medium size one-family house, painted gray -- tri the edges of the frame -- the yard is surrounded by well- yard is mostly green grass and flower beds -- with walkwa front and back of the house. The children and the dog mov the residential street --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They walk around the side of the house to a back door. Th basket down -- DAVID knocks on the door -- after a moment tall, attractive white woman in her early forties, opens

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We brought your laundry, Miss Boatwright.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come in, children. They enter the house, leaving SOUNDER in the backyard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DAVID and EARL stop in the middle of the floor, holding t

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Put it right up on this table, boys.  The two boys lift the basket up on the table. She looks t for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You tell Rebecca ain't a Chinaman in all this  world can beat her ironing. She reaches into her pocket and pulls out some change, pi passes it on to DAVID.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is for your mama's work, and here's  something for the three of you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, Miss Boatwright.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, Miss Boatwright.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, by the way, David, I have the book I  promised you. She moves for another room as the children all look to ea returns immediately with the book, and hands it to DAVID

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's about the Three Musketeers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, Miss Boatwright.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When you read it we'll talk about it...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes mam... We gotta go, Miss Boatwright.. .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell Rebecca I said 'hi', now... The children turn and walk out of the back door --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MRS. BOATWRIGHT is in the doorway as DAVID, EARL and SOUN JOSIE MAE, who stops and turns to MRS. BOATWRIGHT --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's a Chinaman, Miss Boatwright? Before MRS. BOATWRIGHT can struggle up a response --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, Josie Mae! We gotta hurry! JOSIE MAE turns and catches up with them -- they all rush MRS. BOATWRIGHT'S yard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They run up the road and into a field -- continue on acro over a slope until they can see crowds of people at a mak diamond where two teams of black sharecroppers are engage baseball contest. They keep moving on into the crowd --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Men, women and children are standing around, loudly rooti the three children make their way through the crowd to fi NATHAN LEE is pitching on the mound for his team. He thro Batter misses it --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look at Daddy throw that ball! They keep moving until they spot their mother, who is sea another woman. They rush to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rebecca, your children git bigger by the hour!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's the good livin' that do it, Harriet! She smiles as the children approach her. DAVID LEE hands

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss Boatwright gave me this book and all of us  a nickel apiece! REBECCA holds her hand out with palm up as if to say "han three children pass the money on to her --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's winning, Mama?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nobody yet -- it's all tied up. The ballgame goes on as they shout and roar for NATHAN's putting on quite a pitching performance in the close, exc NATHAN's team is at bat -- there are two out -- a man at bat. The man at bat hits a ground ball to the second base trickles away from his glove into the outfield -- he quic ball and tries to make a play at First Base, but the Batt meanwhile the runner on Second has moved past Third Base score -- the first baseman throws the ball to the catcher the runner slides into Home. It is a close play and the u decision to call the runner safe. An uproar takes place a shows its displeasure over the umpire's call -- but the p rooting for NATHAN's team shout and scream in ecstasy. Af order is restored.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NATHAN and his family are on their way home, accompanied friend named IKE. As he plays, he sings one of those basi blues. He finishes the song and gives out with a big laug

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If they heard me sing like this up North I'd be  richer than the man I sharecrop for.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And if they saw me pitch the way I did today --  they'd hire me just to strike out Babe Ruth! NATHAN and IKE give out with a big laugh. REBECCA just sm

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They pass a white church on the road. A number of people yard of the church and some are entering. DAVID watches w

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do they do in the white churches, Mama?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Same as we -- they pray.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, one time by mistake I went into a  white church down in Row County and to this day  I don't know how'n the devil I got outta that  church alive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They probly thought you was crazy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess so -- but I went home and did me some  praying to the Lord. I said, Lord, I went into  this white church down in Row and all I want  you to tell me is how I ever got outta there  in one piece.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did the Lord tell you, Ike?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He said, I don't know, Ike -- you doin'  better'n me, I been tryin' to git in there for  200 years and ain't make it yet! Ike bursts out in loud laughter, joined by NATHAN, REBECC

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If there ever was a devil in this county, Ike,  you is it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ike, you could make a song outta that!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I believe I'll do just what you say, speed ball! They keep moving and come to a stop at crossroad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, this is where I havta say good night to  y'all -- it's been fun, Miss Rebecca.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Us too, Ike.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a good, warm night comin' up, Nathan --  you goin' to the woods?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, yeh -- possums and coons better hide deep  from us tonight! IKE moves away from them -- As they continue on home they singing to himself --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The dark has set well as the family approach the house. S growl -- the children stop, and DAVID LEE turns his head

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's two men in front of our house, Daddy. They all stop -- and can see the shadowy figures of two m their yard, and a Pick-Up Truck parked off the road towar the cabin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who is they?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Children, come here... The children move back -- NATHAN LEE looks behind himself fields as if he would like to make a dash for it -- but R every physical and mental motion he makes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We better see who they is... They begin to move slowly toward the house with deliberat two men becoming more visible identifiable with their sho their sides. They move into the yard and stop about twelv men.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SHERIFF YOUNG steps out of the front door of their house. not speak for a moment -- they merely stare at each other family with inquiring and fretful eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We been in your house, Nathan-- NATHAN and REBECCA look to each other with knowing glance

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We found what we was lookin' for. He moves away from the door and stops at the edge of the

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You took some food and stuff from the James'  Smoke House last night so me and my deputies  here gon' hafta take you to the County Court  House. SHERIFF YOUNG nor the DEPUTIES make a physical move towar long moment of tense silence. For a second, NATHAN seems desperate break and run, but REBECCA holds him by the arm strength her hand can afford.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, boys... The DEPUTIES move in and take NATHAN by the arms from bot handcuffs on him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What they doin', Mama?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Be quiet, son... EARL falls into his mother's embrace - suddenly, SOUNDER' the atmosphere, and for the first time the DEPUTIES draw waist level --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shut that mongrel up! DAVID runs to SOUNDER and tempers him as the sound fades dog frantically scratches the earth as DAVID holds on to

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Git that truck up close here, and quick! One of the DEPUTIES moves out in a hurry to fetch the veh YOUNG moves down the steps into the yard and looks to DAV

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now boy, if you love that dog, you better keep  a good, strong hold on him. The sound of the truck is heard moving up close to the ho REBECCA moves away from JOSIE MAE and EARL, and stops dir SHERIFF YOUNG.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You been knowin' Nathan for a long time,  Sheriff Young, and you know what kind of man he  is, and you know the trouble we face in these  off-seasons. The SHERIFF cannot look her in the face -- he walks away everyone, and just looks out over the fields -- then fina his hand to the two DEPUTIES, standing at NATHAN'S side t truck. They lift him up into the truck as JOSIE MAE, stan with EARL, starts to cry softly as REBECCA moves to the e real close to NATHAN'S face. She kisses him lightly on th they just look on each other for awhile, in a way they kn other so well. Then in a physical, tough manner, REBECCA up on the porch with JOSIE MAE and EARL. One DEPUTY gets in the back of the truck with NATHAN, and the wheel -- as SHERIFF YOUNG climbs up and sits next to

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alright, let's go! The truck starts to pull away -- DAVID lets go of his gri makes a dash out into the road.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't take my Daddy! Please don't take my Daddy!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David, come back here! SOUNDER lets out with his voice, and charges past DAVID f road.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The DEPUTY in the back of the truck aims his shotgun as S truck -- the thunder from the DEPUTY's shotgun is the onl heard in the entire valley -- SOUNDER falls to the road.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: REBECCA rushes down from the porch to the edge of the yar

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DAVID keeps running in the direction of the truck and SOU He sees SOUNDER rise and fall, give out with a faint yelp the field. He moves in the direction of the house, fallin with the hind part of his body staying up -- moving from DAVID arrives at the spot where the animal was cut down, deadpan on the truck as it fades from his view. He looks of blood in the sand -- reaches down and digs his fingers his hand up and frowns -- looks out into the field to tra movements -- then makes his way back to the cabin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DAVID trots back to the front yard -- REBECCA is at the e JOSIE MAE and EARL are still on the porch -- DAVID keeps house -- REBECCA stares down the road -- in her backgroun DAVID and the lighted lantern can be seen faintly, crawli JOSIE MAE and EARL come down from the porch, and stop jus mother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mama, why did they take Daddy away?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because he cared so damn much about you and me,  child.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is he gon' be gone long?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Might be...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DAVID LEE, with the lantern, crawls about under the house

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sounder... Sounder...  He stops and looks all around him with a pained expressio SOUNDER is not under the house...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The following morning REBECCA pours the walnuts from the bag and proceeds to tie the bag up as DAVID LEE looks on. enter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Josie Mae, I'm goin' into town for awhile to  see about your Daddy -- David Lee is gon' be in  charge here, so you and Earl do just like he  tells you. She steps out of the front door with DAVID -- JOSIE MAE a move through the yard, and on to the road leading away fr

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: REBECCA and DAVID LEE slowly move along up the road.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Watch the fire -- don't go too far lookin' for  Sounder, and warm up some of that corn mush for  y'all to eat. If anybody comes to the house  that's a stranger to you, don't say nothin'. They come to a halt at a short distance from the house -- softly down on the boy for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Bye, Mama...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Bye, son -- I won't be gone long. The mother and son move away on the road with their backs DAVID LEE picks up speed and runs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As JOSIE MAE and EARL look on, DAVID LEE completes buildi wood stove. He warms up and serves corn mush to his siste EXTs. BACKYARD, UNDER CABIN, ROAD, FIELDS, WOODLANDS - DA DAVID LEE chops wood at the woodpile -- rakes up a few ch and heads back into the house. He crawls under the cabin, searching about carefully, loo The boy charges up the road away from the house and then field. He spirals the brown stalk land in ever-widening circles, fence-rows -- and then he comes to the edge of the woodla DAVID LEE searches under the jack oaks and cottonwoods, b there. He stands in one spot, looking about the woods in

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: REBECCA moves into town, picking up the main street, cros moving in the direction of SHERIFF YOUNG's office which i County Court House.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SHERIFF YOUNG is seated behind his desk -- a DEPUTY is si across the room. REBECCA enters and stands before the SHE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Howya do, Rebecca. I sorta been expectin' you  this mornin'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wanta see Nathan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wish I could, Rebecca, but I can't let you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't understand that, Sheriff Young.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's the rules and I gotta follow 'em. No  visitin' 'cept holidays and Sunday -- and no  womenfolk anytime.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean to tell me I can't see my own husband?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's the way they do things here in Landsdown.  I just follow orders.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got to see my husband, Sheriff Young!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd like to help you, Rebecca. But all that  would do, is git us both in trouble.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will they give him a trial?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shore thing -- next week sometime, and as soon  as I git the day, I'll ride out and let you  know 'bout it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You gotta low-life job, mister sheriff! REBECCA turns and storms out of the SHERIFF'S office and

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: REBECCA walks in haste and anger away from the SHERIFF's street of Landsdown.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She even moves past the commissary -- stops and calms her turns around and enters the store.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She moves directly to the counter where an elderly man st the owner of the store and farm owner the MORGAN family s puts the bag of walnuts on the counter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rebecca, you jest the one I wanta see.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I brought these walnuts to trade. He looks into the bag -- then empties the walnuts onto a looks to her...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's one dollar an' twenty cents.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wanta get some things.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hope it ain't a lot,'cause I can't give you  no more credit till the croppin' season gits  back, that is if Na--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't say nothin' 'bout credit, Mr. Howard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whatcha wanta order?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I need some nutmeg, flour, eggs, sugar, and... A few minutes later, he puts her last article up on the c

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now what I wanta talk to you 'bout is Nathan.  He oughtn' done what he did: sneakin' into the  James' place and takin' they goods. That looks  bad on me. I been good to y'all -- didn't I go  to all that trouble to get the people of  Landsdown to let your David Lee go to they  school? Didn't I? With the mood she's in, REBECCA does not have anything to concerning NATHAN, DAVID LEE or that damn school. For a m her to say something and then he goes on --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And another thing; with Nathan stuck in jail  and all, how you gon' crop for me when the  spring season comes, huh? She still can't find words to say to this man, but tries. and a little snap cracks in his voice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dammit, I'm talkin' to you, woman! I gotta farm  to think about and I need answers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The season is a long way off, Mr. Howard, and  by that time, Nathan oughta be home. If he  ain't, believe me -- the children and me -- we  will grow the crops. We have to because we owe  you all that money -- Mr. Howard. What she has just said about the money they owe is a frus HOWARD'S mind as he looks to her helplessly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DAVID LEE, JOSIE MAE and EARL are sitting on the steps, l road.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you think Sounder is dead, David Lee?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will he stay dead?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He ain't dead, now stop askin' crazy questions!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't havta get mad 'cause you didn't find  the ol' dog! JOSIE'S words hit him hard. He looks to her for a moment expression -- turns his eyes back to the road where he sp up the road toward the house from an unidentifiable dista

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DAVID LEE stops in the middle of the yard with his eyes d approaching figure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somebody's comin' here...  JOSIE MAE and EARL move down from the stoop and stand beh eyes dead set on the road.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's Mama! The children run out to greet her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, Mama! They all reach her as she lays some of the packages down

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, Children -- here, take some of these  packages. The children relieve her of all of the packages, and they through the yard for the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you see Daddy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, son. We havta wait 'til the holiday comes  -- anyway, they won't let womenfolk see their  men no time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I go when the holiday comes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You sure can, son... They step up on the porch and move into the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They enter the house and start putting the packages on th

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Any sign of Sounder?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No mam -- I looked all over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think maybe he was scraped on the head by  that shot. I don't think he's dead -- just gone  somewhere to heal himself. She takes out of one of the bags of flour, cocoa, and a s vanilla flavoring. EARL takes out from one of the bags an

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothin' in here, Mama.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm goin' use it to put a cake in and I'm gon'  let David Lee take it to your daddy! As the children help their mother put the things away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mama... Make a chocolate cake... Daddy likes  things that's chocolate! (smile).

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is a small section provided for "colored only" -- REBE DAVID LEE and IKE -- A few other black people are seated overlooking the main courtroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Defendant will rise and come before the bench. They don't even bother to sit -- they stand just inside t watch in intense silence. NATHAN moves slowly before the stops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nathan Lee Morgan, you have been found guilty  of unlawful trespass and robbery -- do you have  anything to say before sentence is passed?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (almost in a whisper).

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, sir...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is the judgment of this court that you be  remanded to the custody of the sheriff of this  county and that you be taken forthwith to serve  a term of one year at hard labor at such county  labor camp as shall be hereafter designated.  Next case, please... They watch two guards lead him from the courtroom in hand on sadly as REBECCA cringes at the sight of the Guards ta

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From the top of the Court House building, REBECCA, DAVID seen, slowly walking across the square, moving farther an

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: REBECCA hangs out clothes - DAVID LEE draws water from th wrings the water out of the clothes -- EARL pours water i

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DAVID LEE, on his way to school, is late again -- enters dashes into the building.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DAVID LEE roams about the woods, alone, in the hope that SOUNDER.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DAVID LEE reads from "The Three Musketeers" to REBECCA, J It is very funny -- they laugh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DAVID LEE, in the shed takes his father's baseball glove -- puts the glove on -- holds it up, and then slaps his f several times -- stops and looks off into blank space -- straight ahead as if he can visually see his father off f

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sunday, REBECCA and the children -- DAVID LEE carrying th their way down the street -- people are moving back and f dress. They move into the Square at the Court House.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the square, they come to a halt as REBECCA looks up at the Court House building. It is about ten minutes to twel continue on around to the back of the building --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They stop in front of a huge back entrance and look up to with prison bars. A number of black people are moving int about and waiting as REBECCA and the children are.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Be sure to ask your daddy to tell you what camp  they goin' to send him to. And whatever you do in there, David Lee, act perkish, and don't  grieve him. The clock above the Court House strikes twelve times. The intensity until the twelfth stroke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, son, that's it -- now don't forget  what I told you. DAVID LEE moves through the doorway with the other people

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DAVID follows the other people down the corridor and then stairs -- then down another corridor. They line up at a h DAVID touches the MAN in front of him on the arm --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This where you go visit, mister?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door swings open and a red-faced Guard at a table jus begins to admit people. DAVID's turn comes and the Guard

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whatcha got there, boy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A cake for my Daddy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, you put it on this table here'n wait 'til  I check it. DAVID puts the cake on the table just inside the door as the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can't be too careful, boy, jest might have a  steel file or hacksaw in it. The GUARD opens the box, pulls from his pocket a switchbl slow deliberation punctures knife holes in about fifteen the cake. After he is done, he closes the box and rises.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's your daddy's name?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nathan Lee Morgan...  The GUARD checks his list on the table --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, boy, fourth cell down there on your left. DAVID moves inside --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DAVID LEE moves along the corridor, looking from one side men sitting on cots and standing behind iron gates. He co and there is his father, standing with his hands on the b

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, looka here...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, Daddy...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi to you, son... He extends his hands and they shake -- and then he draws embraces him --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mama is outside with Josie Mae and Earl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They is!? It shore is good to see you, boy! Finally DAVID passes the box with the cake on to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This was a real cake before the man at the door  put all these holes in it. NATHAN takes the box and immediately opens it --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aw, don't make no difference, son. If I know  your mama, a few knife holes ain't gon' destroy  the soul she put into this cake. Come on, have  a piece with your daddy. NATHAN breaks a piece for himself and passes another on t a bite out of the cake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We didn't find Sounder yet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He'll show up one day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you think he's dead, Daddy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Naww -- he'll come back to you, soon as his  wounds heal. This cake shore is tasty, son. He walks away from the cell door and moves to the window up with his back to DAVID.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a shame they won't let 'em come in here.  If I had the strength I'd knock down these damn  walls -- if I could just git my arms 'round  your mama right now -- is they on this side of  us, son?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think so... NATHAN jumps up to the window a couple of times until his grip around the bars of the small window -- he strains an get his eyes up to the window level --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dammit! I'm gon' see 'em if I have to break my  arms! NATHAN finally gets his eyes up to the window -- he looks them --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can see them! I can see them! His arms give way and he drops back to the floor on his f slowly to DAVID and takes him by the arms through the bar

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Son, don't ever let yourself get caught in a  place like this. There is a moment of agonizing silence as they look at ea

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can you say what camp they gon' send you to,  Daddy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know, son -- they won't tell us things  like that -- but I don't want y'all to come  here no more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why, Daddy; you won't be here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just do like I tell you -- I'll get word to you  through the visitin' preacher.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Visitin' over! People start filing out but DAVID remains in front of the his father --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, boy!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go, son... NATHAN and DAVID shake hands and then DAVID slowly moves sporadically looking back over his shoulder toward his fa through the cell block door -- the door slams behind him

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DAVID steps out into the Court House yard where they are his feelings bound in confusion, and his face flooded in his mother's arms. She embraces him long and deep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: REBECCA and the children attend services at the Church -- standing -- they are in the midst of a song, led by the P Like everything else in Landsdown for Black People, it is structure with creaky, movable chairs for the worshipers are two high windows on both sides. The Pastor reads the verses of the song in the traditiona Preacher's fashion, and the congregation repeats the vers Song --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coffee, cold drinks, cookies and fruit are being served t chattering crowd of church goers -- inside a woman is at rhythmic uptempo gospel songs. IKE is there also. REBECCA, with HARRIET in line behind her, and the childre the table to be served.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If this wasn't a church, I'd do me a dance to  that music she's playin'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why don't you try it, Harriet, and just see  what everybody would do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, Rebecca, I may be a country woman, but I  ain't no fool. REBECCA and HARRIET take coffee and cookies at the table take fruit. They move across the floor for a corner to si little moving dance step as they arrive to the corner and

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You determined to get that dance in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, you can't blame a girl for tryin' if the  feelin' hits her. REBECCA notices the PREACHER talking to a group of women

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I don't go over there and butt in, I ain't  gon' ever get to talk to the Preacher about  Nathan. She rises and moves across the floor. DAVID LEE watches c approaches the PREACHER and gets his attention by touchin and they move off to a more secluded spot in the Church. moves to join their company.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I ain't got no word yet, Rebecca. I went to  the courthouse yesterday to see 'bout it, but  they just won't tell me nothin' about what  labor camp Nathan was sent to. I'm sorry,  Rebecca.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a shame, Reverend. It's a damn shame.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hope you don't take to bitterness, Sister  Morgan. I tell you like I tell all the women in  this church who got the same trouble you got.  No matter what the trial or what the misery is,  I tell 'em to stay with God.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, he'll crawl into my bed tonight, lie  close to my body and keep me warm -- and  rectify the evil in the men who live over us  in this valley.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not that simple, Sister Rebecca -- the  Lord works in mysterious ways -- we come into  this life with nothin' and we'll leave it with  nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that a blessing, Reverend? Her words jar and disturb the PREACHER --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: REBECCA and the children are just about to enter the yard stops and pulls on his mother's arm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mama, did you hear that?!  REBECCA, JOSIE MAE and EARL come to a halt on his words.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is it, David Lee?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen, Mama... They stand quietly for a moment -- and then they hear the whine coming from the direction of the porch -- the whine

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mama, I hear Sounder! He takes off in the direction of the porch --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DAVID stops just at the top of the porch, and there, scra and wagging his tail, is SOUNDER. The side of his head wh him is discolored and hairless -- the top of his eye is s be half-closed, and what's left of his ear on the same si out. Upon seeing DAVID LEE, he raises his good ear and wh to grab him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You come back, boy! I just knowed it! I just  knowed you'd come back! REBECCA, JOSIE MAE and EARL arrive at the porch -- REBECC the bad sight of the dog and strokes his back --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Poor creature...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He'll be all right, Mama. I'll make him all  right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The next morning, DAVID LEE feeds SOUNDER as EARL stands

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He eats all right -- his throat ain't scarred.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then why don't he holler like he usta?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He will... Come on, git down and act like a  possum.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't look like no possum!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Act like one!  After a moment of hesitation, EARL gets down on his hands

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Git him, boy! EARL jumps to his feet quickly and backs away across the

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't tell that dog to git me!  SOUNDER merely turns to DAVID LEE and gives out with a fe

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess I'll havta work harder to git him back  like he usta be.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why don't you try and git you a new dog? DAVID LEE takes off after EARL who turns, breaks and runs field --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: REBECCA, DAVID LEE, JOSIE MAE and EARL up in the field, w hoeing and cultivating the soil -- SOUNDER trots about th vicinity of DAVID LEE --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: REBECCA is looking on about three hundred feet away as DA with SOUNDER in open field, trying to work him back into halfway picks the dog up -- drops him to the ground, take SOUNDER does not follow him. He comes back to the dog and affectionately -- takes off and runs again -- this time, after him. REBECCA and DAVID look to each other and smile success!! He caresses and hugs the dog -- they move towar and they start walking back toward the house -- and then they and the dog take off in speed with huge raindrops sp their faces and bodies. From the field, as they make a ru figures become smaller as they near the backyard and the home...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A bright sunny day -- DAVID LEE is just about to quit for gardening work he is doing for MRS. BOATWRIGHT -- He move house to put some equipment away when the lady approaches

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David, you never cease to amaze me at how good  you are in taking care of my garden.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My father taught me...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you like to have a cool drink, David?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, thank you -- I gotta go do some work in the  field today. DAVID starts to walk away and then decides to stop, turns heading back into the house --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss Boatwright --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (stops, turns)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, David...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will you help me to find out what camp they  sent my father to?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The courthouse has rules about things like that,  David -- but I'll ask around town about it. He looks on her with an expression of disappointment, tur

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See you tomorrow, Miss Boatwright.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (turns to her)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, ma'am...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll find out where your daddy is for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiles)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, Miss Boatwright!  (turns and runs away)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't mention this to anyone! You hear me,  David! He just keeps running --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DAVID LEE, at top speed, runs into the front yard from th the side of the house through the back yard and on into t of the house, heading for the crop field.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: REBECCA, JOSIE MAE and EARL are working the field as DAVI towards them --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mama! Mama! Miss Boatwright, say she gon' help  me find where Daddy is!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good! But you don't have to tell the whole  valley 'bout it! You'll get that woman in  trouble!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHARLIE DAVID, the Court Clerk, is standing behind his de BOATWRIGHT is seated in a chair before his desk. There ar small office, a coat rack in the corner diagonally behind chairs, another small working desk, and a row of file cab wall --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't do it, Rita -- that's the policy here  on colored prisoners, and I ain't about to  change it, not even for a friend like you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie, just because a man and his family are  colored, you--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now look, Rita, I don't make the rules -- you  puttin' yourself on a limb, comin' here, askin'  me to do a thing like this. And I be damn if  I'm going to jeopardize my job because you are  in love with a little colored boy! The phone on his desk rings -- he picks up the receiver t down --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: County Clerk's office, Charlie Davis  speaking... Yes, sir... You bet your life,  sir...Yes, sir, I'll be right there. He puts the receiver down -- jumps up, goes to the rack a starts to fix his tie --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That was Judge Elliot on the phone and when  Judge Elliot calls, I jump! Good day, Rita. He moves to the door, to the waiting area and opens it to can be seen standing in the background of CHARLIE --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But, Charlie --

dialogues.speaker: NO
dialogues.text: Just like that he is gone. MRS. BOATWRIGHT stands in the in a moment of frustration, with DAVID LEE looking on fro thinks for a moment and then looks to the file cabinets a DAVID stands in the doorway as she decides to go to the f checks the outer notation on each one of the cabinets unt one that reads: PRISONER CASES. She quickly opens the cab hurriedly fingers through the files until she finds the f MORGAN's name on it. She goes through it until she has go she wants and just as she is about to put it back, CHARLI and has caught her in his files. She looks cheaply to him back into its place, closes the cabinet drawer and backs cabinet. He moves past DAVID LEE into the office on to th she was, opens it enough for him to tell that she has dis single file of NATHAN LEE MORGAN. He slams the file drawe turns to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I see you found what you was lookin' for.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I did look, Charlie, but I--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No buts, Rita!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie, you have no legal right not to let  this boy know where his father is! You hear  that, you and this whole damn court house;  what you are doing is wrong!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't tell me about what's wrong. You come into  my office as a friend and steal city files! I  could have you arrested for that -- and if you  give out that information to anybody, that's  exactly what I'm going to do -- and I'll tell  everybody in this town how you got the  information and who you got it for! You won't  have a friend left in this county to bring you a piece of candy!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You would do that, wouldn't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You getting the point, Mrs. Boatwright. MRS. BOATWRIGHT gives him a hard and long look with the f what he says --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's get out of here, David Lee. She turns and moves out of the office, through the door, following --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MRS. BOATWRIGHT and DAVID are slowly descending the Court towards her automobile, parked about a hundred feet away. open the door of the car, when DAVID LEE stops --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know where my father is, don't you, Miss  Boatwright?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, he was wrong, David, I didn't find out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I saw you -- you looked in there, and you  found out, Miss Boatwright.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I tell you I didn't, David, that's what I  mean.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But, Miss Boatwright, you--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know a damn thing, now stop bothering  me about it! She gets into the car as he shuffles his feet about on th head turned slightly down, remaining in one place --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come, I'll take you home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll walk...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't pout now, David, it's a long trip.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm used to it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, you can't say I didn't try. DAVID LEE watches her drive off and away and then he slow away...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DAVID LEE, at the well, draws up a pail of water and pour container for SOUNDER who is standing beside him, anxious water. As SOUNDER drinks the water, DAVID turns around to standing in the middle of the yard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, David...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, Mrs. Boatwright... (pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry 'bout the way I acted the other day,  Miss Boatwright.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's nothin' to be sorry about, David --  where's your mother?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right here, Miss Boatwright. REBECCA is standing in the doorway of the shed -- MRS. BO quite know how to begin -- the two women just look to eac -- then --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The camp Nathan is at is called Wishbone Labor  Camp. It's in Nolan Town! REBECCA lets the news soak in for a moment -- DAVID LEE h his face. REBECCA moves from the doorway and stands direc BOATWRIGHT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss Boatwright -- you shore is a crazy actin'  woman sometime! She bursts out laughing and kicks up her leg -- DAVID pic then MRS. BOATWRIGHT... EARL and JOSIE MAE arrive and sto the house -- can't quite make out what this crazy laughin they move to the center of the yard with them and join in After a short while the laughter comes to a sudden stop - silence --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mama, what was we laughin' for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the way you ask funny questions, Josie Mae!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the house, REBECCA and all the children are gathered a BOATWRIGHT at the table with a map spread out as she scan a pencil --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We go from "A-2" -- now let me see where we go  from here...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Trouble, Miss Boatwright?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh no, these maps are easy to read. But she is having trouble locating the place as her penci several confusing spots on the map -- like having to find indicating alphabet and number in order to search about a smaller town -- but finally --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There it is, right there! She makes a marker with the pencil and holds it down on t everybody leans over the map as close as possible to see has made a circle around -- DAVID straightens up --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you get there, Miss Boatwright? Everybody straightens up to get MRS. BOATWRIGHT's directi map up as they look on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now they have numbers and letters on here to  tell you where to look on the map, but Nolan Town is not under a number but we know it's in  Northern Landsdown -- the number for Northern  Landsdown is: "h7", but since Landsdown is the  largest county, it actually stretches over into  "a2" but "a2" is -- Am I making myself clear?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's clear, Miss Boatwright -- it's so clear,  you don't havta go any further -- thank you -- when the time comes for us to find that place,  we will -- won't we, children?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: REBECCA and DAVID LEE are hoeing as JOSIE MAE and EARL ru grooves planting seeds -- REBECCA and DAVID complete thei down on the ground out of exhaustion as JOSIE and EARL mo seeding the last grooves of earth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: REBECCA is sitting in her rocker, knitting, when DAVID LE room -- she turns and looks to him --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can't sleep?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, ma'am... (pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mama, I wanted Mrs. Boatwright to find out  where Daddy is, so me and Sounder can go see  him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So did I. I figured when the time got right,  we could all take a day or two and walk up  there, but it's not the kind of long trip for a  child to take alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can do it, Mama -- you know that. In the  Bible stories you read to us, everybody's  always goin' on a long journey. Jacob goes  into a strange land where his uncle is and he  don't even know where he lives, but he finds  him. Everybody finds what they supposed to  find.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you'll be away from home for days -- what  will you do when the dark comes, where will  you sleep? I can't send you away from here  like that!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mama, don't I always do what you say -- every  time I go to the fields to plant the corn, to  Miss Boatwright's and the woods -- you tell me  what to do and I do it, and you don't worry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I don't and I oughtn't not to after the way  you've taken over since they took him away --  and I would like for you to see 'im so you can  come back and tell me about 'im.  (pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The field's all planted, so I guess I can spare  you for a little while. When do you wanta  leave? REBECCA gets up from the rocker and starts putting her kn dresser --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I go day after tomorrow?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, son. You better get back to bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good night, Mama...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good night... He turns, moves out of sight into his room. REBECCA gets puts her knitting away, picks up the map MRS. BOATWRIGHT dresser, and spreads it on the table to the light of the make sense of the map -- she folds it back up and shoves looks across the room in thought.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two days later, a little after daybreak, DAVID is all set with SOUNDER -- DAVID is at the table -- IKE is standing writes on a piece of paper -- REBECCA and the other child

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now afta you go by Nolan, the first road you  come to is Jordan road -- keep walkin' on that  road and you'll run right into it. It's a long  trip, David Lee, so good luck to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, Mr. Ike... They all turn around and move out the front door --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They move out the house and down into the yard and stop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wish you wouldn't take the dog with you,  David -- he's likely to be a burden to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got to, Mama. I know Daddy wants to see him. REBECCA passes on to him a big brown bag of food --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here's your food -- now you go straight to that  place -- if you need to rest, go into a church  or railroad station -- but don't go into  nobody's house, you hear me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, mam...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ask your daddy to give you some word about when  he'll be comin' home -- and tell 'im we love  him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell 'im I said, "Hi", too, David. REBECCA pulls him into her arms --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good luck to you, son... (releases him)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right now, get movin', you losin' daylight. DAVID gives quick embraces to JOSIE MAE and EARL -- and t hit the road -- JOSIE MAE and EARL, follow him part the w back up on the porch, stops and turns in time to see DAVI and EARL "goodbye" -- JOSIE MAE and EARL move back toward the boy and dog slowly fade from her view...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DAVID LEE and SOUNDER walk the road. They pass a cabin, w is working.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DAVID and SOUNDER are in a small cubby hole of the statio overheard that reads: "Colored Waiting Room." He is looki newspaper as a man in a chair across from him is fast asl finally he too falls asleep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DAVID goes in the water to cool off and refresh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DAVID and SOUNDER come upon a sign in front of a migrator that advertises: "Fruit pickers and sorters needed."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DAVID works sorting fruit for part of the day and after h a bite to eat --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Back on the road as DAVID LEE and SOUNDER continue their through an area with landscapes and mountains, the size a has never seen. At one point, he stops and looks on in wo

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DAVID LEE washes a car as SOUNDER looks on. A man pays hi the piece of paper with IKE's directions and then they mo

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DAVID and SOUNDER approach the camp. He moves close to a WISHBONE LABOR CAMP, NOLAN COUNTY. They move on farther along the barbed wire barricade of t they come to a halt when DAVID sees two lights and a wide entrance with two guards just inside the gate. They move sloped hill just beneath the entrance of the camp. They l to sleep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is early morning as DAVID is awakened by the voices of motor of a truck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whatcha got for me today!?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Same bunch you had yesterday!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I'll take what I kin git! DAVID hears the truck motor into the grounds of the compo crawl up to the edge of the slope so they can see. Finall across the road to the gate where the guard is --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DAVID and SOUNDER approach the gate and stop -- one of th and walks over --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mister, can you visit anybody here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gotta wait 'til visitin' days.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When's that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sunday...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you know my daddy, Nathan Lee Morgan?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Never heard of 'im. We gotta lotta men here... The sound of the truck, approaching --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, boy, outta the way, truck's  comin'... He opens the gate as DAVID and SOUNDER scatter back acros OTHER GUARD calls out --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Section J comin' through!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let 'er roll! The truck motors through the gate and stops just outside his final check of the men. DAVID, from where he is stand thoroughly to see if his FATHER is on the truck. A number through the gate and DAVID checks them all thoroughly, bu on any of them. Finally the last truck comes out-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Last one comin' atcha!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me have it! The truck pulls to a halt just outside the gate, and DAVI the truck carefully us the GUARD makes his check --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He gotta be on this one, Sounder, it's the last  truck. There are not too many men on this truck which makes it q to see that his father is not on it. Then where is he? Th himself as he sees the truck move away up the road. The t more than about twenty miles an hour -- DAVID LEE makes a off after the truck, running --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A half hour later, the truck with the convicts pulls into the TWO GUARDS jump down from the truck and herd the men third guard gets out of the cab -- and they distribute fa men. A picket fence stretches the area where the men work

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some minutes later DAVID LEE and SOUNDER, walking, approa where the convicts are, moving along the road outside of They stop -- DAVID watches the men work and the guards, c distances of about three hundred feet in a half moon form DAVID decides and moves to the fence to question the men. edge of the road next to the fence, one of the guards spo moving over --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mister...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boy, where did you come from?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wanta find out 'bout my Daddy. Is he here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can't you see that guard comin'-- git!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whatcha doin' here, boy, move! DAVID hurriedly gets back across the road with SOUNDER an as he moves the men back. DAVID looks on in frustration, what his next move will be -- The guard moves away from t to another guard to engage him in a conversation -- while rapping with each other, DAVID decides to make a desperat

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, Sounder, let's go! DAVID LEE and SOUNDER dash across the road, and slip unde farm area --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DAVID LEE and SOUNDER turn on all the speed they can must for the group of CONVICTS -- They get there --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please tell me, mister! Is Nathan Lee Morgan  here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is nobody name Morgan! Now get away from  here before you git us in trouble! SOUNDER lets out a growl at one of the Guards who is now them. DAVID takes off in a circle with the Guard in pursu the direction of the road -- SOUNDER is close behind him into the direction of the road and zoom past the group of is running at electrifying speed. DAVID and SOUNDER are m the Guard still after the boy. They come to the fence and through, but DAVID's hand falls on a broken bottle with g leaps up and continues on across the road and into an ope stops at the edge of the road and gives up the chase --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DAVID and SOUNDER are still running with great speed.  DA his shoulder to see if the Guard is still after him. They approach an old abandoned barn --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He staggers into the barn and drops his body against one catch his breath. SOUNDER hobbles in and nestles beside h

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DAVID, holding his hand, sits on the road with the dog -- before his eyes -- it is practically covered in blood. A causing him to grimace for a moment -- looks about the ar start out once again --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry, Sounder, but we lost. Better keep movin'  though, 'til we find somebody to tell us how to  get back home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They come upon a large schoolhouse with the name over it: They stop when DAVID sees a number of Black Children play -- climbing on little ladders and swinging on swings. He on the grounds, looks at his blood-covered hand -- hesita then decides to enter the grounds --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DAVID and SOUNDER head straight for the pump and just as pump a group of Children gathers around them --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You new here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You comin' here to school?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's wrong with that dog? Two dogs near the side of the schoolhouse bark at SOUNDER and scratches back at them but their barking intensifies attractive black female teacher interferes --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on now, get away from here! The two dogs gallop off as do the Children -- they scatte DAVID and SOUNDER. The TEACHER walks over to DAVID and st

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just wanta wash my hand. It's got blood where  I hurt it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't live around here, do you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, mam... I come from way back there. Me and  my dog was tryin' to find my daddy and we got  lost.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
